titlestmt.titleproper: Inventory of the Benjamin C. Willis papers
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Samira Bozorgi

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2017-11-21T17:36-0800
profiledesc.langusage: Finding aid is written in English

change.item: Descriptions of audio recordings updated, including new shelf locations, by Jim Sam.
Motion picture film locations edited by Vishnu Jani.
Descriptions of reformatted audiovisual items updated.
Descriptions of reformatted sound recordings added.

physdesc.extent: 362 manuscript boxes, 6 oversize boxes, 4 motion picture film reels

did.abstract: Minutes and verbatim transcripts of meetings, statistics, reports, correspondence, speeches, sound recordings, and motion picture film relating to public education in Chicago. Digital use copies of selected items also available.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Use copies of some sound recordings in this collection are available for immediate access. To listen to other sound recordings or to view videos, films, or digital files during your visit, please contact the Archives at least two working days before your arrival. We will then advise you of the accessibility of the material you wish to see or hear. Please note that not all material is immediately accessible.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Benjamin C. Willis papers, [Box no.], Hoover Institution Archives.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Acquired by the Hoover Institution Archives in 1982.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Materials may have been added to the collection since this finding aid was prepared. To determine if this has occurred, find the collection in Stanford University's online catalog at http://searchworks.stanford.edu/. Materials have been added to the collection if the number of boxes listed in the online catalog is larger than the number of boxes listed in this finding aid.

eventgrp.event: Bachelor of Arts, George Washington University

chronitem.event: Superintendent of public schools in Yonkers and Buffalo, New York
Superintendent of public schools in Chicago, Illinois
Proposal to purchase aluminum portable classroom units approved by Chicago Board of Education

Protested by Martin Luther King Jr. and other civil rights leaders for using portable classrooms, or "Willis Wagons" as they were called by protesters, to relieve overcrowding at schools in Chicago's South Side
Helped develop the federal Vocational Education Act
Helped develop the federal Elementary and Secondary Education Act
Worked as an independent educational consultant
Superintendent of schools in Broward County, Florida

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: This collection is comprised of the office and personal files of Benjamin Coppage Willis, documenting his activities as superintendent of Chicago schools and as a major figure in public education from 1953 to 1969, represented in the form of minutes and verbatim transcripts of meetings, reports, correspondence, speeches, printed matter, photographs, sound recordings, motion picture film, and memorabilia.

The majority of Willis' papers focus on his meetings, interactions, and engagements with the Chicago Board of Education, its members, and critics. Minutes and verbatim transcripts from meetings, correspondence, reports, and conference materials are included in this portion of the collection and focus mainly on the topics of curriculum development; enrollment figures; grants; school budget and finances; mobile classrooms; teacher education; and collective bargaining.

The sound recordings of Board of Education meetings in the collection were originally aired on Chicago public radio from 1962 to 1966. Some of the programs include a segment featuring Willis called "Dr. Willis Reports." Materials relating to Willis' symbolic (and temporary) resignation from the Board of Education in 1963, spurred by the Board's decision to alter the student transfer policy, are included in the collection in the form of correspondence, public statements, superintendent contract files, photographs, and printed matter.

Accompanying these materials are Willis' research findings, reports, ledgers, correspondence, speeches, and photographs from conferences on the advancement of vocational education programs in urban cities. As a major proponent of vocational education, Willis helped found the Great Cities School Improvement project, which later changed its name to the Research Council of the Great Cities for School Improvement Program. The group held conferences across the United States, collaborated with administrators and Board of Education members from major U.S. cities, and participated in congressional hearings to advance education policies, standards, and sources of funding. Conference materials include reports and presentations on topics relating to teacher education, grants and funding, and the special needs of children in urban schools.

Other materials in the collection include correspondence, daily planners, yearbooks, and printed matter from Willis' early career in education, as well as reports, speeches, conference materials, and correspondence from Willis' time in the AASA and as superintendent of schools in Broward County, Florida.

did.unittitle: Christmas program: Barton School chorus, Morgan Park High School chorus,
At Random television program, sound recording

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The sound track of a television program, including commercials. The labels on the source tapes indicate this comes from WBBM-TV.
The program is a discussion on several local issues to Chicago, such as, but not limited to, schools, busing, and funding the police and fire departments.
There are occasional drop-outs in the audio, such as around 24:20 in part 3. These are heard on the source tapes.

scopecontent.p: Fantasia by Walter Hendl. Hymn to Democracy by Howard Hanson. Walter Hendl conducts both selections. 12-inch lacquer disc.

did.unittitle: H. Miller air check sound recording,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Miller defends Benjamin Willis as an outstanding school administrator, pointing out that Massachusetts hiring Willis from his current job in Chicago is a compliment to the city. Recorded by WIND radio. 10-inch lacquer disc.

did.unittitle: Benjamin Willis speech: "Start School, When School Starts,"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Willis asks every boy and girl to enroll in school and stay in school. 10-inch lacquer disc.

did.unittitle: Party at Houston's and other miscellaneous sound recordings,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 11 July 1950: The school board of Yonkers pays tribute to Benjamin Willis as he relocates to Buffalo. Part 1, Bill Dickson, Wm Lally, John Class; Part 2, Wm Lally, B.C.W.; Part 3, B.C.W., Class; Part 4, Class, Collins; Part 5, Collins, Sheets, Burke, Riley; Part 6, Minnervini, Elkind, Campion; Part 7, Rachel, singing "Auld Lang Syne" and "For He's a Jolly Good Fellow".

Part 8 on 17 July 1947: Officials of Yonkers, New York introduce Benjamin Willis, the recent appointee as school superintendent. Speakers are George Schiele, John Class, Hilda; Part 9, Hilda, Rachel Jr.; Part 10, Rachel Hons of Rest. Taken from original sleeves with speaker information written on them.
Set of five 12-inch lacquer discs.

did.unittitle: William C. Diehl farewell speech for Benjamin Willis,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: William C. Diehl delivers a speech about Benjamin Willis on the occasion of Willis' departure for a new job. Prior to Mr. Diehl's address, Mrs. Irene Hutzell offers a brief address to Willis concerning a gift from his office. 12-inch lacquer disc.

did.unittitle: Washington County Hillbillies musical performance of Mr. Willis Said,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This is about Benjamin Willis' work with the Washington County schools. 12-inch lacquer disc.
